caption: Figure 1: Comparison of in-sample and out-of-sample mean squared error (MSE) across various degrees of clustered noise. The vertical line indicates p = n (= 1,415).
description: This figure compares the in-sample (training) and out-of-sample (test) mean squared errors (MSEs) for a linear regression model with different levels of clustered noise in the regression errors.  The x-axis represents the number of predictors (p), and the y-axis represents the MSE.  Multiple lines are shown, each corresponding to a different level of clustered noise (controlled by parameter 'c').  The vertical line at p=n highlights the point where the number of predictors equals the sample size. The plot demonstrates how the MSE behaves in different parameter regimes with varying degrees of clustered noise.

caption: Figure 2: Our theory (dashed lines) matches the expected variances (solid lines) of the prediction (left) and estimation risks (right) in Example 2.1 (AR(1) Errors). Each point (σ², ρ²) represents a different noise covariance matrix Ω, but with the same Tr(Ω) along each line {(σ², ρ²) : σ²/κ² + ρ² = 1} for some κ² > 0, they have the same expected variance. We set n = 50, p = 100, and evaluate on 100 samples of X and 100 samples of ε (for each realization of X) to approximate the expectations.
description: This figure validates the theoretical findings of the paper regarding the prediction and estimation risks in the context of autoregressive errors. By comparing the theoretical predictions (dashed lines) against the empirical results (solid lines), the figure showcases the accuracy of the theoretical model across a range of noise covariance matrices.  The key takeaway is that the expected variances remain consistent even with varying covariance structures, as long as the trace of the covariance matrix remains constant. This is demonstrated through multiple contour lines, each representing a different trace, and demonstrating the consistent agreement between the theoretical and empirical results.

caption: Figure 3: Our theory (dashed lines) matches the expected variances (solid lines) of the prediction (left) and estimation risks (right) in Example 2.2 (Clustered Errors). Each point (σ², ρ²) represents a different noise covariance matrix Ω, but with the same Tr(Ω) along each line {(σ², ρ²) : σ²₁ + σ²₂ = κ²} for some κ² > 0, they have the same expected variance. We set G = 2,(n₁ = 5,n₂ = 15),n = 20, p = 40,1 = ρ₂ = 0.05, and evaluate on 100 samples of X and 100 samples of ε (for each realization of X) to approximate the expectations.
description: This figure compares the theoretical predictions (dashed lines) and empirical results (solid lines) for the variance of prediction and estimation risks in a clustered error scenario.  It demonstrates that the theoretical model accurately captures the variance, even with varying degrees of correlation within clusters, as long as the trace of the variance-covariance matrix remains constant.

caption: Figure 4: The "descent curve" in the overparameterization regime for prediction risk (left) and estimation risk (right). We test Ω's with Tr(Ω)/n = 1,2,4 in black, blue, red, respectively. For the anisotropic feature, the expected variance (×) and its theoretical expression (●) are (Tr(Ω)/n) and larger than that in the high-dimensional asymptotics for the isotropic ∑ = I. For the isotropic ∑ = I, the variance terms (dotted) and the bias terms (dashed) in the high-dimensional asymptotics are limn→∞ Tr(Ω) and r²(1 − n/p), respectively.
description: This figure shows the double descent phenomenon for both prediction and estimation risks in the overparameterized regime (p>n).  It compares the actual variance and bias (obtained through simulations) with their theoretical counterparts under different assumptions about the covariance matrix of the regression errors (Ω). The plot shows how the variance and bias change as the ratio of the number of features (p) to the number of samples (n) increases.  The results illustrate the impact of the trace of Ω on both risks and highlight the difference between isotropic and anisotropic feature spaces.  Isotropic refers to the case where the features are independent and identically distributed, while anisotropic represents a more general setting with correlation between features.

caption: Figure 3: Our theory (dashed lines) matches the expected variances (solid lines) of the prediction (left) and estimation risks (right) in Example 2.2 (Clustered Errors). Each point (σ², p²) represents a different noise covariance matrix Ω, but with the same Tr(Ω) along each line {(σ², p²) : σ² + p² = κ²} for some κ² > 0, they have the same expected variance. We set G = 2,(n₁ = 5,n2 = 15),n = 20, p = 40,1 = p2 = 0.05, and evaluate on 100 samples of X and 100 samples of ɛ (for each realization of X) to approximate the expectations.
description: This figure compares the theoretical predictions (dashed lines) with the actual experimental results (solid lines) for both prediction and estimation risks in a clustered error scenario.  The results show a close match, validating the theoretical analysis that the trace of the variance-covariance matrix (Tr(Ω)), not the specific structure of the matrix itself, primarily determines the expected variance. Each line represents different error covariance matrices with the same trace. The parameters are set to illustrate the relationship between theory and experiment.
